color:#000000; border-left-width:medium">\n         2,527.7\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr style="text-align: center;">\n        <th scope="row" style="height: 16px;">\n         Percent\n         <a href="/wiki/Sunshine_duration" title="Sunshine duration">\n          possible sunshine\n         </a>\n        </th>\n        <td style="background: #FBFB2A; color:#000000;">\n         48\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF33; color:#000000;">\n         50\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF47; color:#000000;">\n         55\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF4F; color:#000000;">\n         57\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF57; color:#000000;">\n         59\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF6C; color:#000000;">\n         64\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF63; color:#000000;">\n         62\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF63; color:#000000;">\n         62\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF5B; color:#000000;">\n         60\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF57; color:#000000;">\n         59\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF33; color:#000000;">\n         50\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #F6F61E; color:#000000;">\n         45\n        </td>\n        <td style="background: #FFFF4F; color:#000000; border-left-width:medium">\n         57\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td colspan="14" style="text-align:center;font-size:95%;">\n         Source: NOAA (relative humidity and sun 1961\xe2\x88\x921990)\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NWS_Baltimore.2FWashington_.28LWX.29_64-2">\n          <a href="#cite_note-NWS_Baltimore.2FWashington_.28LWX.29-64">\n           [62]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NCDC_TXT_KDCA_77-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-NCDC_TXT_KDCA-77">\n           [73]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WMO_1961.E2.80.9390_KDCA_72-1">\n          <a href="#cite_note-WMO_1961.E2.80.9390_KDCA-72">\n           [70]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Apr_trace_snow_78-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-Apr_trace_snow-78">\n           [74]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">\n        Cityscape\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Streets_and_highways_of_Washington,_D.C." title="Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.">\n        Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.\n       </a>\n       ;\n       <a href="/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_Washington,_D.C." title="Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.">\n        Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.\n       </a>\n       ; and\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Washington,_D.C." title="List of tallest buildings in Washington, D.C.">\n        List of tallest buildings in Washington, D.C.\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="450" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg/220px-L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg/330px-L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg/440px-L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:L%27enfant_plan_of_Washington_DC.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         L\'Enfant Plan for the federal capital city\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Washington, D.C., is a\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_town" title="New town">\n        planned city\n       </a>\n       . In 1791, President Washington commissioned\n       <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Charles_L%27Enfant" title="Pierre Charles L\'Enfant">\n        Pierre (Peter) Charles L\'Enfant\n       </a>\n       , a French-born architect and city planner, to design the new capital. He enlisted Scottish surveyor\n       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Ralston" title="Alexander Ralston">\n        Alexander Ralston\n       </a>\n       helped layout the city plan.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-c109_79-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-c109-79">\n         [75]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/L%27Enfant_Plan" title="L\'Enfant Plan">\n        L\'Enfant Plan\n       </a>\n       featured broad streets and avenues radiating out from rectangles, providing room for open space and landscaping.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lenfant_80-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-lenfant-80">\n         [76]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       He based his design on plans of cities such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">\n        Paris\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">\n        Amsterdam\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Karlsruhe" title="Karlsruhe">\n        Karlsruhe\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">\n        Milan\n       </a>\n       that\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">\n        Thomas Jefferson\n       </a>\n       had sent to him.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">\n        <a href="#cite_note-81">\n         [77]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       L\'Enfant\'s design also envisioned a garden-lined "grand avenue" approximately 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) in length and 400 feet (120\xc2\xa0m) wide in the area that is now the National Mall.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">\n        <a href="#cite_note-82">\n         [78]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:L%27Enfant_plan.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3404" data-file-width="4179" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/L%27Enfant_plan.jpg/220px-L%27Enfant_plan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/L%27Enfant_plan.jpg/330px-L%27Enfant_plan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/L%27Enfant_plan.jpg/440px-L%27Enfant_plan.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:L%27Enfant_plan.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/L%27Enfant_Plan" title="L\'Enfant Plan">\n          L\'Enfant Plan\n         </a>\n         for Washington, D.C., as revised by\n         <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Ellicott" title="Andrew Ellicott">\n          Andrew Ellicott\n         </a>\n         in 1792\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       President Washington dismissed L\'Enfant in March 1792 due to conflicts with the three commissioners appointed to supervise the capital\'s construction.\n       <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Ellicott" title="Andrew Ellicott">\n        Andrew Ellicott\n       </a>\n       , who had worked with L\'Enfant surveying the city, was then tasked with completing the design. Though Ellicott made revisions to the original plans, including changes to some street patterns, L\'Enfant is still credited with the overall design of the city.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">\n        <a href="#cite_note-83">\n         [79]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       By the early 1900s, L\'Enfant\'s vision of a grand national capital had become marred by slums and randomly placed buildings, including a railroad station on the National Mall. Congress formed a special committee charged with beautifying Washington\'s ceremonial core.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ramroth_35-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-ramroth-35">\n         [33]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       What became known as the\n       <a href="/wiki/McMillan_Plan" title="McMillan Plan">\n        McMillan Plan\n       </a>\n       was finalized in 1901 and included re-landscaping the Capitol grounds and the National Mall, clearing slums, and establishing a new citywide park system. The plan is thought to have largely preserved L\'Enfant\'s intended design.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lenfant_80-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-lenfant-80">\n         [76]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg">\n         <img alt="A tall red brick building in the center of a city skyline punctuated by steeples and other shorter buildings." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg/220px-The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg/330px-The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg/440px-The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Cairo_Building_in_Washington_DC.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The construction of the 12-story\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cairo_Apartment_Building" title="Cairo Apartment Building">\n          Cairo Apartment Building\n         </a>\n         in 1894 spurred the city\'s\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Height_of_Buildings_Act_of_1899" title="The Height of Buildings Act of 1899">\n          first building height restrictions\n         </a>\n         .\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       By law, Washington\'s skyline is low and sprawling. The federal\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heights_of_Buildings_Act_of_1910" title="Heights of Buildings Act of 1910">\n        Heights of Buildings Act of 1910\n       </a>\n       allows buildings that are no taller than the width of the adjacent street, plus 20 feet (6.1\xc2\xa0m).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schwartzman_84-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Schwartzman-84">\n         [80]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Despite popular belief, no law has ever limited buildings to the height of the United States Capitol or the 555-foot (169\xc2\xa0m)\n       <a href="/wiki/Washington_Monument" title="Washington Monument">\n        Washington Monument\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legend_54-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-legend-54">\n         [52]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       which remains the District\'s tallest structure. City leaders have criticized the height restriction as a primary reason why the District has limited affordable housing and traffic problems caused by urban sprawl.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schwartzman_84-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Schwartzman-84">\n         [80]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The District is divided into\n       <a href="/wiki/Quadrants_of_Washington,_D.C." title="Quadrants of Washington, D.C.">\n        four quadrants\n       </a>\n       of unequal area:\n       <a href="/wiki/Northwest,_Washington,_D.C." title="Northwest, Washington, D.C.">\n        Northwest (NW)\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Northeast,_Washington,_D.C." title="Northeast, Washington, D.C.">\n        Northeast (NE)\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Southeast,_Washington,_D.C." title="Southeast, Washington, D.C.">\n        Southeast (SE)\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Southwest,_Washington,_D.C." title="Southwest, Washington, D.C.">\n        Southwest (SW)\n       </a>\n       . The axes bounding the quadrants radiate from the U.S. Capitol building.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dcstreets_85-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-dcstreets-85">\n         [81]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       All road names include the quadrant abbreviation to indicate their location and house numbers generally correspond with the number of blocks away from the Capitol. Most streets are set out in a grid pattern with east\xe2\x80\x93west streets named with letters (\n       <i>\n        e.g.\n       </i>\n       , C Street SW), north\xe2\x80\x93south streets with numbers (\n       <i>\n        e.g.\n       </i>\n       , 4th Street NW), and diagonal avenues, many of which are\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_state-named_roadways_in_Washington,_D.C." title="List of state-named roadways in Washington, D.C.">\n        named after states\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dcstreets_85-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-dcstreets-85">\n         [81]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The City of Washington was bordered by Boundary Street to the north (renamed\n       <a href="/wiki/Florida_Avenue" title="Florida Avenue">\n        Florida Avenue\n       </a>\n       in 1890), Rock Creek to the west, and the Anacostia River to the east.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neighborhoods_33-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-neighborhoods-33">\n         [31]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lenfant_80-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-lenfant-80">\n         [76]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Washington\'s street grid was extended, where possible, throughout the District starting in 1888.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">\n        <a href="#cite_note-86">\n         [82]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_street_renaming" title="Georgetown street renaming">\n        Georgetown\'s streets\n       </a>\n       were renamed in 1895.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tindall_34-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Tindall-34">\n         [32]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Some streets are particularly noteworthy, such as\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)">\n        Pennsylvania Avenue\n       </a>\n       , which connects the White House to the Capitol and\n       <a href="/wiki/K_Street_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="K Street (Washington, D.C.)">\n        K Street\n       </a>\n       , which houses the offices of many lobbying groups.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kstreet_87-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-kstreet-87">\n         [83]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Washington hosts 177\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Washington,_D.C." title="List of diplomatic missions in Washington, D.C.">\n        foreign embassies\n       </a>\n       , constituting approximately 297 buildings beyond the more than 1,600 residential properties owned by foreign countries, many of which are on a section of\n       <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)">\n        Massachusetts Avenue\n       </a>\n       informally known as\n       <a href="/wiki/Embassy_Row" title="Embassy Row">\n        Embassy Row\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-embassies_88-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-embassies-88">\n         [84]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">\n        Architecture\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1196" data-file-width="1614" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG/220px-WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG/330px-WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG/440px-WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:WhiteHouseSouthFacade.JPG" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">\n          White House\n         </a>\n         ranked second on the\n         <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects" title="American Institute of Architects">\n          AIA\'s\n         </a>\n         "\n         <a href="/wiki/America%27s_Favorite_Architecture" title="America\'s Favorite Architecture">\n          List of America\'s Favorite Architecture\n         </a>\n         " in 2007.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The architecture of Washington varies greatly. Six of the top 10 buildings in the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects" title="American Institute of Architects">\n        American Institute of Architects\n       </a>\n       \' 2007 ranking of "\n       <a href="/wiki/America%27s_Favorite_Architecture" title="America\'s Favorite Architecture">\n        America\'s Favorite Architecture\n       </a>\n       " are in the District of Columbia:\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">\n        <a href="#cite_note-89">\n         [85]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       the\n       <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">\n        White House\n       </a>\n       ; the\n       <a href="/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral" title="Washington National Cathedral">\n        Washington National Cathedral\n       </a>\n       ; the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson_Memorial" title="Thomas Jefferson Memorial">\n        Thomas Jefferson Memorial\n       </a>\n       ; the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol" title="United States Capitol">\n        United States Capitol\n       </a>\n       ; the\n       <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial" title="Lincoln Memorial">\n        Lincoln Memorial\n       </a>\n       ; and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial" title="Vietnam Veterans Memorial">\n        Vietnam Veterans Memorial\n       </a>\n       . The neoclassical, Georgian, gothic, and modern architectural styles are all reflected among those six structures and many other prominent edifices in Washington. Notable exceptions include buildings constructed in the French\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Empire_(architecture)" title="Second Empire (architecture)">\n        Second Empire\n       </a>\n       style such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Eisenhower_Executive_Office_Building" title="Eisenhower Executive Office Building">\n        Eisenhower Executive Office Building\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nps_90-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-nps-90">\n         [86]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Outside downtown Washington, architectural styles are even more varied. Historic buildings are designed primarily in the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Anne_Style_architecture" title="Queen Anne Style architecture">\n        Queen Anne\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teauesque" title="Ch\xc3\xa2teauesque">\n        Ch\xc3\xa2teauesque\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Richardsonian_Romanesque" title="Richardsonian Romanesque">\n        Richardsonian Romanesque\n       </a>\n       , Georgian revival,\n       <a href="/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture" title="Beaux-Arts architecture">\n        Beaux-Arts\n       </a>\n       , and a variety of\n       <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">\n        Victorian\n       </a>\n       styles. Rowhouses are especially prominent in areas developed after the Civil War and typically follow\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_architecture" title="Federal architecture">\n        Federalist\n       </a>\n       and late Victorian designs.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">\n        <a href="#cite_note-91">\n         [87]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Georgetown\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Old_Stone_House_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="Old Stone House (Washington, D.C.)">\n        Old Stone House\n       </a>\n       was built in 1765, making it the oldest-standing original building in the city.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">\n        <a href="#cite_note-92">\n         [88]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Founded in 1789,\n       <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_University" title="Georgetown University">\n        Georgetown University\n       </a>\n       features a mix of Romanesque and\n       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">\n        Gothic Revival architecture\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nps_90-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-nps-90">\n         [86]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Building" title="Ronald Reagan Building">\n        Ronald Reagan Building\n       </a>\n       is the largest building in the District with a total area of approximately 3.1\xc2\xa0million square\xc2\xa0feet (288,000\xc2\xa0m\n       <sup>\n        2\n       </sup>\n       ).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">\n        <a href="#cite_note-93">\n         [89]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">\n        Demographics\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Washington,_D.C." title="Demographics of Washington, D.C.">\n        Demographics of Washington, D.C.\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <table class="toccolours" style="border-spacing: 1px; float: right; clear: right; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; text-align:right">\n       <tr>\n        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="4" style="padding-right:3px; padding-left:3px; font-size:110%; text-align:center">\n         Historical population\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr style="font-size:95%">\n        <th style="text-align:center; border-bottom:1px solid
